description.text: My kids want to have Percy Jackson themed costumes, and I was chosen to be Poseidon. I wanted to have a Trident as part of the costume, so i remixed this!

Printer:

Marvin

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Used Hatchbox Gold PLA with slic3r's new cubic fill pattern. The only reason I used a raft is to counter the sag of my X-axis over its span.

I liked shinyrobot's trident design, so I remodeled it in Solidworks 2016 and enlarged it to the max. size my printer can handle.

I also added broom handle threads to attach it to. According to my limited web research, broom threads are supposed to be 3/4"-5 Acme threads, but I modified this standard to fit what I have for a broomstick (and my printer may not be perfectly calibrated for internal features, so YMMV).

I do have SolidWorks 2016 file if anyone wants to play with this design further.

HAPPY PRINTING!

author: wheelguy10X

description.text: mount your gopro to the rod of a bike seat

print_settings.Notes:: If scaling the lattice to maximum size for your printer causes the small details in the connection sites to be too small to print, you can either use the "Separate Connected Surfaces" tool in the Mesh tab to allow yourself to delete individual triangles to make the lattice smaller, or you can use the included "KagomePositive" and "KagomeNegative" files to construct your own ideal size lattice.

description.text:
The Kagome Lattice is one instance of a geometric structure called uniform tiling. Specifically, the Kagome Lattice is a type of trihexagonal tiling, where a repeated structure is made up of triangles and hexagons. I learned of it through a presentation at a meeting of the physics group I work for at Brandeis University. While I can't claim to know much about what physical systems this lattice represents or what special properties it has, I do know that it has a very interesting method of folding and I wanted to see it happen in real time.

This lattice prints entirely in place with no raft, no supports, and no assembly required. It works right off the build plate, which was a goal of mine that I'm thrilled to have achieved. Each connection site has ~120 degrees of rotational freedom. You can either scale down the STL or 3MF file I've included to fit your printer, or you can manually create a lattice of the size you want by translating the individual triangles to their appropriate spot using the "KagomePositive" and "KagomeNegative" files I've included.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.200

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I highly suggest using the "Horizontal Size Compensation" tool in the "Other" tab of the Simplify3D Process Settings. This will ensure that the connnection sites don't fuse and that you can rotate each triangle easily. I personally set it to -0.10mm compensation as any more would remove some of the mesh, but play around and see what works for your printer. Additionally, I used the "Scale to Maximum Size" tool in the Edit tab to easily get the lattice to fit the printer I used, and manually adjusted the z-axis height to my desired 3mm.

If scaling the lattice to maximum size for your printer causes the small details in the connection sites to be too small to print, you can either use the "Separate Connected Surfaces" tool in the Mesh tab to allow yourself to delete individual triangles to make the lattice smaller, or you can use the included "KagomePositive" and "KagomeNegative" files to construct your own ideal size lattice.
Give each individual connection site a bit of a twist to break any strings that might have formed mid-printing and you're done!

I used Autodesk Fusion360 to design the basic positive and negative pieces. Parametric CAD made this an incredibly easy process and I got to try out some new tools I hadn't used before like creating a new axis and patterning faces circularly about the center of an object.

It made of ABS for durability. The orientation during printing is like on photo 4. Basic settings: Layer height: 0.2 Walls: 1.2 Fill: 20.

Already in use for more than 5000 km without any problems.
Hope there is someone that can use it.

We had some broken frames around the house which needed repair.
I saw a similar clamping system and decided it would be an easy print.

This design works and I don't intend to update. If I was starting over, I would consider designing the knobs into some type of gear that I could drive with a drill since it takes a lot of turns with long threaded rod.

The printed parts are very simple, just print four of each piece. I used four pieces of 1/4"-20 threaded rod and 12 nuts. For the knobs, I heat up my capture nut and pull them into the piece. The nut internal to the corners is simply inserted.

title: Yet another level test, with small circles and OpenSCAD source
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yes, yet another level test.

This does nine circles across the bed and these have circular holes in the middle (so like washers) as I find small circles one of the best tests of a level bed.

It's only a single 0.2mm layer thick, so prints very quickly. You should easily be able to see where you might need to tweak level.

Circles remove easily with a razor blade - see the EZ Snap holder on Thingiverse.

I printed this out of ABS and yes it shrunk so I scaled each part by 1.50mm in all directions

Its not perfect as the cables out the side of the dot are close and end up being buried in the plasterboard. I had to relieve the back side of the plasterboard to allow it to fit.

I used a 92mm hole saw

Dont bother with the hole fixings, I ended up bonding it in place (not the dot jut the bracket).

My advice would be to trial a fit on a peice of 12mm/12.7mm plasterboard before committing yourself to a large hole in your wall!!!!!

I also spray painted the outer ring just so it was bright white.

You may also have to to a little filling with decorators caulk as this one has straight sides but it is very minimal.

description.text: A friend wanted a VanHalen logo but I wasn't thrilled with the ones I found so I made one. This logo has a channel in the top to give it some class as well as a hole in the middle of the back so you can add a magnet later or possibly stick it on a stand.

Depending on whether you add a layer of felt on the inside of the holder to protect the stick's surface you might need to change the with of the model. (Currently 1,5mm felt should work.) Additionally, the base is rather high, I did not want the taped stick knob to touch the wall. Kevin Klein used a lot of tape, that's why the base needed to be 10mm.

description.text:
This mod is for all of you like me who wanted a light in the Skull Lantern using an off the shelf tea light.

There are multiple sizes to fit the various tea lights available.

I have tried this with a warm (and not so bright flickering tea light pictured above) as well as a cool super bright LED. Both are cool and provide different end results.

To assemble you need:

1 Bottom
1 Skull
1 Middle
1 Top
1 Handle
1 Clip Holder
1 Tea Clip (match your sized tea light)
1 Spring (to match your tea light size)

NOTE: I don't have a 40 mm tea light so I didn't test that size. Let me know if it or the spring needs adjustment.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.27mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Use 2 shells on the skull and low infill for better light penetration. I tried 10% infill on the skull but 5% might work fine.

1 Glue Skull to base (not required but HIGHLY recommended)
2 Glue bottom to middle
3 Glue Middle to Top
4 Snap in Handle
5 Snap spring on Tea Light Clip
6 Slide Tea Light Clip on to Clip Holder
7 Slide in Tea Light rotated so you can access the On/Off Switch if aplicable
8 Snap Clip Holder into bottom

I used DesignSpark Mechanical to design the new components, but it was choking on modifying the original STLs so I ended up using 3D Builder to Merge in the Clip Holder Receiver and cut a hole in the back wall and skull. Unfortunately, 3D builder did something weird when saving the STL and I had to repair it in MeshMaker.

This is a mounting plate for the dual motors driver board that uses a L298D. They are widely available. This mounting plate serves three purposes:

  • act as a spacer between the mounting surface and the board (4 mm)
  • prevent scratching the mounting surface
  • prevent short-circuiting the board component pins if the mounting surface is metallic.

The mounting holes are 3 mm in diameter. They are pass-tru holes. They are 36.75 mm apart. The mounting plate is 43.3333 mm x 43.3333 mm. The overall height of the mounting plate is 4 mm.

description.text:
A model aircraft whistle printed for a friend to attach to his radio-controlled glider (quite a big aircraft!)

I don't know how well it works, but he seemed pleased with it. Comments welcome for my benefit and others.

The whistle is in two parts: a lid (which does the whistling) and a resonant chamber. The pitch is determined by the depth of the chamber. It is set to quite a high pitch to keep the weight of the whole thing down.

The aerowhistle is designed in FreeCad, and is parametric. You can adjust the dimensions in the design spreadsheets. This is a first-shot with guessed dimensions. I have no doubt it could be improved. Feel free to leave comments for the benefit of others.

Assembly

Glue the "lid" onto the "whistle". Attach to the aircraft with velcro. Or perhaps make the whistle deeper and design it into the fuselage. We've not tried that, but then you wouldn't need a dog to hear it for you :) (it's quite high pitched at the current dimensions)

title: K-Cup Adapter for PVC Pipe Dispenser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Like many people, I require coffee in the morning to help me begin to human correctly. Also like many other people my household has a Keurig. Only problem is now I have to keep track of dozens of Kcup pods.

The current storage options for kcups either didn't fit well where I store the Keurig, took up too much space or were just didn't do it for me. So I designed this adapter to be able to easily turn 2 inch PVC pipe into a custom sized KCup dispenser that is easy to load.

Whoa, wait a minute there. What were you doing when you found out K cups fit into PVC pipe?! Um... story for another time? Or... ask my wife?
Wait. No. Don't ask her... Lets just say I was drinking coffee while helping a friend with a different project and realized K cups and medium size potatoes are roughly the same diameter...

This design is pretty straight forward. If you'd like more info a step by step instruction of how to make and assemble the K-Cup Adapter for PVC Pipe Dispenser can be found on Instructables: https://www.instructables.com/id/3D-Printed-PVC-Pipe-K-Cup-Dispenser/

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I have printed these in PLA and ABS successfully.

The ABS version may fit a little tighter since it shrinks more than PLA when it cools. Depending on how dialed in your settings are light sanding may be required.

3 files are attached. One for just the dispenser base, one for just the pipe support and a file with both the base and the support combined.

Glue the base to the PVC pipe

I recommend using hot glue or super glue to secure the adapter base to the PVC pipe.

STEPS:
1) Use Cyanoacrylate to the fan screw holes to fix 4 x M3 nut threads.
2) Use the 2 x M3 screws to fix the extruder motor to the extruder carriage.

5) Print or feel free to remix the STL file to improve your 3D printer.
6) use 1 x M3 (50mm long aproximetly) and 1 x M3 nut thread for the hinge.

author: Eckythump

title: mgn12 mod ( Anet A8 / AM8 ) - build plate for simplify3d
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
With Simplify3D you can customize print bed visualization with your own STL file.
This model will add a ghosted version of your Anet Blv mgn12 mod printer.
Main purpose is indicate model scale on your printer.

Change log:

7/1/18 An Optimized STL model with more details at 3 variations:

  • Full model
  • Naked model
  • Bed only model

Instructions (Pc users):

1.Copy both stl files into directory: "C:\Users***USERNAME***\AppData\Local\Simplify3D\S3D-Software"

2.within Simplify3D app go to File > "Export FFF Profile"

3.open the profile file you exported with a text editor

4.change the lines:

<overridePrinterModels>0</overridePrinterModels>
<printerModelsOverride></printerModelsOverride>

if you want full printer model change to:
<overridePrinterModels>1</overridePrinterModels>
<printerModelsOverride>Blvfull.stl</printerModelsOverride>

or you want printer model with bed only, change to:
<overridePrinterModels>1</overridePrinterModels>
<printerModelsOverride>Blvbed.stl</printerModelsOverride>

or you want naked printer model, change to:
<overridePrinterModels>1</overridePrinterModels>
<printerModelsOverride>Blvnaked.stl</printerModelsOverride>

5.Save the file

6.Go back to Simplify3d and import back the fff profile you saved.

7.enjoy :)

comments.text: How would I make my own version of this?

Its not that difficult,
You need to crated a model of your printer with first origin of it starting with the bed 0,0 position.
Then, just export the complete STL and add to Simplify3d.

Allow 3 of the corners of the build platform to be adjusted while limiting one side's compliance in the X dimension. I have a set of small springs, and knobs to adjust the height of the bed. The nuts are: http://www.mcmaster.com/nav/enter.asp?partnum=93886A110
The springs were something I had lying around... I hate it when people say that because now what are you supposed to do? Hopefully for you the reader, either you don't care and your just reading this for charity, or you or someone else cares enough to find something and then post it or make a derivative. Keep the bar end that has the adjustable stop. This will set the height of the bed (you can adjust the zstop to this height. Use the tabbed end at the other end of that Y Bar. This needs a spring as pictured. Your build platform will require a small hole to attach. The long tab will limit the build platform's compliance in the X direction The smaller Y bar ends may be used on the opposite bar as pictured. They're designed to be compliant in X, though you may have to drill out the holes a bit. You'll notice mine are at a bit of an angle because My y bars are wider than intended in the original Printrbot design. Tightening the original parts would have broken the plastic and/or caused the Y bar bearings to be unessecarily loaded. (It was my fault, I didn't drill out the holes for my x bars before installing, so the carriage is too large.

comments.text: I should probably build a boss around the part that's splitting to both strengthen it and to relieve stress on the flexible portion.
comments.author: drewmacrae

comments.text: I've been printing with these for a while now, and qualitatively I get the feeling these help to stabilize the bed. I haven't come up with a meaningful way to benchmark this stability to verify my claim. The adjustable knobs work, but the springs aren't always strong enough to push the bed up over the threads of the screws.

author: PrimalR0de0

title: Heatsink support for Raspberry Pi 3 - Overkill Cooling Solution
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A large cooling solution for Raspberry Pi 3.

I'm using one as CCTV for 2 USB camera with full HD video capture and the Pi get way to hot, causing it to throttle and ending up by a beautiful crash of the Raspberry Pi. I needed to cool it down, I have tried with a small heatsink but it doesn't cool it enough. So I ordered 40x40x18mm heatsink online (Farnell.com) and stop to a local electrical workshop near my town to ask a cut of 6mm tick and flat copper bar. They had one in their waste bin waiting for me :D

Oh and don't forget to put some thermal paste between CPU and copper block, and also between copper block and heat sink... (never know who will complain if I don't mention that)

Files are:

  • PCB isolation for the piece of copper (way larger than the cpu on the board)
  • Copper alignment and raiser
  • Support to clamp the cooler down on the copper and keep everything tight (using the flexibility of the PLA, so printed part will slightly bent).

I wanted to remix a thing from Snille (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2469031) but he worked with Sketch Up (I'm not using it) and shared original design with me. But enable to work with SketchUp, I ended redesigned everything by myself on SW.

The RPi is now running at 50degC with 2 of its core running at 100% speed at all time. Nice and cool, now clock speed is not reduced and the RPi doesn't crash anymore.

I wrote this very quickly if you want more pictures, or more details comment out, I will do my best.

For tubular flashlights with 20mm diameter tube(for example Olight S20 baton).

For this mount you need:
-1 x TPU mount part
-2 x PLA support parts
-2 x 20mm M3 bolts
-2 x M3 nylock nuts

Mounting point to handlebar with 25mm / 1" tube with 20mm long M3 bolts and nylock nuts. Nylock nuts recommended as they don't roll open in continued vibration.

Mount is designed to be printed in TPU / other flex material, could work in simple PLA, but i doubt that. Print the fastener/support bits in PLA/ABS/PETG or something similar that can withstand some forces. All major stress goes to TPU part.

Print with supports and 85 - 100% infill for rigidness. Print mount lying down, so that the flashlight mount faces up(if flashlight was inserted it would point up).

This is tested and found out to hold the flashlight really well.

Updates:

  • 26.10.2017 co-worker noticed that the support structure between mount points was a see-through kind of thing. Noticed a missing join operation in fusion 360 and fixed it in v3.2. V3.1 fastener works with 3.2 same way as before.

title: LACK Attack #2: Casterate the Lack (aka Roll The Lack Stack)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a followup to:
Lack Attack#1: Stacking the Lack: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2586887
without further adieu....

Attack 2: STACK THE LACK

NOTE: SAVE THE SPARE LEGS! If your following this build, you need them for LACK ATTACK #4.

Once I had a 4 Lack Stack with one Lack without Legs on the bottom as a base sitting in my living room I wanted a way to move it easily once it was complete. I knew it would need to move to clean/make room when company comes over (I like to print/work in the living room so I can watch the kids as well) so I also picked up a set of RILL casters at ikea (Article Number : 966.713.00) they were in the discount bin as the bag was ripped, $6, can't beat that...

I didn't see anything similar, so based on the Lack Stack adapter I knocked out a quick caster adapter for the bottom corners that would also serve as a corner protector for the legs as they tend to collect dings easily.

I built these to install 2 ways, I first used them with the posts which will press into the tables screw holes, this was intended to align them, see how they fit, and if they needed modification before I screwed them in place. It worked well for the first couple days and was surprisingly stable, but then one post broke so I screwed them down and into place. I'd skip the posts if I printed these again and go straight to #6x1" screws

As always, comments are greatly appreciated, in this case direction and pitfalls to watch for are also appreciated, If you've been here done this and have a better way please let me know.

Next:
Attack 3: Power the Lack Stack...
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2599482

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.35mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Printed in white NGEN, 240C nozzle, 85C bed.
I printed these as oriented in the STL on edge.
The walls are fairly thin, and infilling can cause surface bumps.
I increased the wall count to 3 to strethen up the one corner and stop any attempts to infill or void on the walls.

Build & Assembly Notes:

Print it x4, pop it off,
slide the casters into the cutouts,
pop the posts into the holes (if you decide to go that route),
press them into the holes on the bottom of the table used as a base,
and stack....
If your happy with how they look, predrill and add at least 2 screws per caster, 4 optimally.
Not much harder than that....

Revisioning:

v1.0 - initial release.

author: SoundDoc

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in PLA

description.text:
This was my first creation for printing, it turned out better than I had expected. Definitely the key piece that defines Cloud's outfit for any cosplayer wanting to go with that look from Advent Children.

My only concern is with removing the support material from inside the mouth. Take extra care to not damage any of the teeth. The ring pieces snap together to fit into the mouth. I intentionally attached the larger set of fangs on the front together, so they would not break as easily and ensure the ring stays there.

There's a gap on the back side for if you would like to attach a pin, or simply glue it to the pauldron as I have.

title: Exhaust Enclosure and Storage Box for Epilog Zing 6030 (Back)

description.text:
This box attaches to the left side of an Epilog Zing 6030 Lasercutter. It provides protection for the exhaust outlets, by tunneling the air to the front and back, as well as storage for documents, rulers and other things.
It only covers the rear half of the Lasercutter's left side. Watch out for the front box design, which will be much more sophisticated.

The design was made with 4mm thick wood in mind and fits on 6 DIN A3 (420x297 mm) plates. I personally used wood for the outer walls and the floor (located above the exhaust vents) and cardboard for the divider walls inside.
The Box dimensions are: width: 282.7mm, height: 397.5mm, depth: 150mm + 11mm (for hooks attaching to exhaust outlets). See the pictures for the attaching mechanism.
There are four storage compartments: two for rulers and "long things" (should be longer then 30cm, otherwise they disappear) and two for DIN A4 documents.

description.text:
Since I've just been putting the stuff I'm printing on Thingiverse, I made these 1.5" beads to make a poi/attached juggling set. Turns out with 275 paracord you can also use them similar to astrojax (with 3 beads) Monkeyknuckles (with 4 beads), or just poi (I like using 3 beads as weights)

The beads are about 35g each printed solid out of pla, and there's 2 styles, one without a cord knot recess, and one with a cord knot recess.

There aren't many flats on this, so unless you have a magic print surface supports are recommended (I used circular, was pretty easy to remove and sand afterwards)

Happy juggling!

title: DC42 IR Probe mount for Updated E3D v6 (IR Sensor,Mini Differential IR Height Sensor)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a IR Probe mount that is designed and made by David Crocker (DC42) to attach to the updated E3D v6 (Smaller heater block and silicone socks).

I was looking for this design and found a few people with issues fitting the current designs to the updated block.

It was designed in Fusion360 by importing the original fan shroud model from E3D and using it as a template for the shape - thus unaffected airflow.

The board is attached slightly off-center so that the IR reading point is in a perfect line with the nozzle. This way you only have a Y offset of 16mm) and no X offset (more accuracy).

There is a small cutout to allow enough room to attach the Molex Connector.

The screw holes are designed for a perfect fit and do not require any drilling or modification from the supplied screws (IR Probe Screws and E3D v6 Fan Shroud Screws).

Please ensure your fan shroud is mounted in the correct way (with the lip pointing up) as it is in the last picture.

No

0.2mm

100%

title: 3 wheels RC / 3 Roues RC - 2 versions
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Here is a radio controlled 3 wheeled vehicle, which looks like nothing special.

It has, for front wheels, large ball bearings inclined on a low axis.
The ball bearings come from the Airsoft 6mm balls.
The tires were printed in Innoflex 60 (more flexible than the Pla).

The engine is a NTM Prop Drive Series 28-26A 1200kv (short shaft version) motor installed in the rim and bolted to the fork.
The steering is ensured by a 9 gram servo hobby, inserted in its support which is attached to the aluminum tube.

Base and hood were printed without support
The motorized fork is printed with support

• Production to PLA and Innoflex 60
• Layer thickness 0.3 mm
• Thickness of hll 1mm
• Filling 20%
• Température 220C°
• Support none
• The 2 square tubes are 75x75 mm aluminium with a length of 125mm
• Engine NTM Prop Drive Series 28-26A 1200kv (short shaft version)
https://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/uh_viewItem.asp?idProduct=39314
• The servo used for steering is a 9 grammes
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__662__HXT900_Micro_Servo_1_6kg_0_12sec_9g.html
• La batterie lipo de 3S 11.1V 1300mA
• The black ring on the propulsion tire is a piece of bicycle inner tube (to increase grip on the ground)

Voici un véhicule à 3 roues radio commandé, qui ne ressemble à rien de particulier.

Il a, pour roues avant, des roulements à billes grands formats inclinés sur un axe bas.
Les billes des roulements proviennent des billes Airsoft de 6mm.
Les pneus ont été imprimés en Innoflex 60 (plus souple que le Pla).

La motorisation est un moteur NTM Prop Drive Series 28-26A 1200kv (short shaft version) installé dans la jante et vissé à la fourche.
La direction est assurée par un servo hobbyking de 9 grammes inséré dans son support qui se rattache au tube aluminium.

Le socle et le capot ont été imprimés sans support
La fourche motorisée est imprimée avec support

• Réalisation en PLA et Innoflex 60
• Epaisseur de couche de 0.3 mm
• Epaisseur de coque de 1mm
• Remplissage 20%
• Température 220C°
• Support aucun
• Les 2 tubes carres sont en aluminium de 75x75mm d'une longueur de 125 mm
• Le moteur NTM Prop Drive Series 28-26A 1200kv (short shaft version)

description.text:
Originally taken from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2134970

I liked the model overall, but did not like the uneven base since it caused problems sticking to the bed. I didn't like his recommendation to move the nozzle closer as I don't want to damage the PEI sheet.

Although you will still have to move he z offset to be close, this version will be less problematic. The originally uneven base was rocky too! Plus, do you really care what the bottom looks like? "Man, I really like looking at the bottom of my sculpture. That's the coolest part!"

I recommend 0.1 mm layer heights. Any higher and you lose a lot of detail. Any lower, and it gets messy, risks jamming, and other random problems along with taking two days to print at around 0.05 mm layer heights.

comments.text: It looks good! I'm grateful for the original guys file, but it took me many more tries than just 3. Eventually I gave up and chopped the base.
comments.author: lch6257

comments.text: Really? When I said third print I meant third item printed after couple test prints. I got this Iron Throne print like this first try. Only issue was a little bit of stringing which I cleaned up with a quick blast from a heat gun. I used latest cura with .15 mm layer height and 205/60 for temps. PLA was Inland - gray 1.75. I wonder why you had the issue? I used glue stick over tape over glass, adhesion was perfect with a raft. If I printed again would use 190/60 for temps to reduce stringing.
comments.author: MasterChief2552

comments.text: First few fails were bed adhesion. At least 6 of those. Then twice the nozzle jammed. This was with my first filament Prusa sent me (It's since been used up and I haven't had problems since). Twice I had software failures with ponterface. There might have been more failures, but I can't remember exactly what they are.

description.text:
This is part of the #RodinRemix project we did with the Portland 3D Printing Lab. Our role was chopping up his sculptures, adding the cavities for the hardware, and delivering to the group for printing. We also had the honor of bringing Mila, one of our printers we've built, to the Portland Art Museum and printing part of one of Rodin's sculptures in the lobby. This re-mixable sculpture is St John The Baptist. This activity was in partner with the Portland Art Museum of the Rodin exhibit. The #RodinRemix part was to educate patrons on the artistic process Rodin used when creating his work, basically remixing parts of his other sculptures to make new sculptures.

Print, glue washers and magnets, enjoy posing in many different remixes!

We supplied washers from here: http://www.homedepot.com/p/Everbilt-1-8-in-x-1-in-Zinc-Plated-Fender-Washer-100-Piece-800362/204276365

Magnets were supplied from here: https://www.ebay.com/itm/25-50-100pc-10mm-x-3mm-3-8-x-1-8-N52-Strong-Rare-Earth-Neodymium-Magnet-Disc-/292085076192?var=&hash=item4401a090e0:m:muHTCIp-5uoTBYDWsHgd1zw

comments.text: The basics are easy.  Download an image that will make an uncomplicated hole in your pumpkin face.  Search Google for "svg image converter."  Upload the image into the converter web site, and it will spit out a Scalable Vector Graphics (.svg) file.  Then you import the blank pumpkin face into Tinkercad, and import the image as well.  Turn the image into a "hole," center it on the pumpkin face, and group them together.

title: Ultimaker 3 Front Door (No Damage to Printer)

description.text:
Finally I have got around to designing a front door for my Ultimaker 3 that looks good, functions well as a heat shield, and does not require any penetration / damage to the original printer. It also hangs neatly on the side when not in use!

My design incorporates a CNC milled front panel. I have included the .STL file & Gcode (mach3) just in case anyone wants to mill their own. Of course a less precise version could be made using conventional tools such as a bandsaw & drill.

The clear front is made from a 4mm polycarbonate called 'Lexan'. I chose this because it mills well, is very impact & scratch resistant. Acrylic would also work of course.

These parts were modelled in Fusion 360.
The front panel for the CNC was also CAM'd up in Fusion 360.

The bolt / nut combination that I used are M3 x 15mm Stainless Steel Hex Head.

I am very satisfied with the finished product.
Please enjoy & let me know if this works for you too!

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This module provides functions below :

  1. totally printable ball bearing spool holder (for spools with >46mm aperture in current version), and a smooth shaft for smaller spools
  2. filament guide
  3. filament filter (optional)
  4. embedded light (optional)

What's special ? Every parts of it are able to be printed by FLUX Delta series !

  • WATCH VIDEO MANUAL AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS PAGE

Printer:

FLUX Delta+

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

More printing settings :

  1. I used Cura 2 slicer to print them
  2. layer 1 temperature is 200°C for PLA
  3. printing temperature is 190°C for PLA
  4. but 210°C all the time when printing " FLUX_spool_holder_bar "
  5. infill with concentric circles when printing light masks for transparent filament

Here's some tips to print them :

  1. Recommended to print every parts in default direction to make them look good.
  2. Print " FLUX_spool_holder_bar " very slowly, set printing speed to 5~10 mm/s, and brim is not needed.
  3. Sometimes the balls in " FLUX_spool_holder_bearing_x2 " don't stick to printing surface well, print this file one more time, then you can get more balls to replace those which looked bad.
  4. Turn off " skirt ", " brim " and " raft " while printing " FLUX_spool_holder_base ", if FLUX Studio still shows oversize notice with this setting, try to switch slicer from Cura 2 to Cura or Slic3r.

About the embedded light :

I used a 100mm " angel eyes " LED to make it, and connected it to the 24V DC power supply in extension port of FLUX Delta+, if you want to make one, read the article below ↓

http://dev.flux3dp.com/tutorials/toolhead_control.html#understanding-the-extension-port

It's also suitable with a common USB LED light, you can just put it above the embedded light mask and plug into the USB port at basement of FLUX Delta+, but hanging a wire at the side of machine doesn't look beautiful lol.

title: Prusa i3 MK2 / MK2S Z-Axis vibration damper

description.text:
When the z-height of my original Prusa i3 MK2S is about 30 mm, the threaded z-axis touches slightly the original (ABS printed) "Z-axis-top-part" and when these elements touch, they generate an irritating vibrating noise while printing. There are many comments on Thingiverse and on the Prusa forum stating that the threaded Z-axis should move freely, which also sounds logical to me.

So to overcome this irritating noise I made this damper which, when printed in a flexible filament, takes away the noise. The wall of the damper is only ~0,4 mm thick and consequently the z-axis has - I believe - still sufficient room to 'wobble'. The damper fits snugly in the hexagon shaped recesses of the z-top-parts.

I printed a set in TPE with a shore hardness 45D. The left damper is a mirror of the right damper and they are marked L and R to make sure you install these on the right place. So far this works fine for me and I have not seen any negative effect on the print quality. Let's see how long they will last :-).

The last photo shows the threaded z-axis touching the damper (z-height at 30 mm) while the other photos show that the z-axis moves freely in the z-top-part including damper.

Pls let me know what you think.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I do not expect that the infill has any effect, since the thin cylinder (only one perimeter thick) does the 'damping' and the hexagon element is only to keep the damper in place - but obviously feel free to experiment :-)

title: Coffee Traveler Lid
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Caution: 3D printed parts are inherently not food safe. Please understand the risks before using this design with anything intended for human consumption.

I looked high and low for a replacement lid to my traveler mugs. After I couldn't find one, I decided to design and print a replacement using my remaining lid as a template. The design is two parts, and it snaps together. An o-ring should be fitted around the bottom part to seal the coffee inside the tumbler mug. I measured 71mm inner diameter and 81mm outer diameter, but I have not yet ordered o-rings to test with. It is compatible with the seal from the original lid, however.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I lowered the hotend temperature and used a part cooler for the overhangs in the bottom-half of the lid. Supports should not be necessary.

Food Safety Warning

Since you will most likely use this thing in and around food, you should think carefully about food safety regarding 3D printing. For instance, do not use ABS filament for this thing, despite it's higher temperature tolerance. It is a toxic material!

I plan to use polyurethane to seal my PLA parts before using the design with food.

Read the information contained on the following page for more information: https://all3dp.com/1/food-safe-3d-printing-abs-pla-food-safe-filament/

description.text:
Here is a plant pot which you can print using 'per part' print settings to achieve a single-layer for the main part. I wanted to use translucent filament so my orchid can get light to its roots. There is not too much ventilation here, use this somewhere warm/dry of if you're forgetful about watering....

There are 3 parts to this model. I wanted to assemble them so the middle section printed in vase mode, but Cura doesn't seem to allow that. One option is to generate G-code for each part, and manually merge the files together (remembering to correct for extruder absolute position). Assuming you don't want to do this:

Configure Cura
Unselect 'keep models apart'

Base Part
No top layer
Make sure the model is centred on the bed.
Enough base layers to get a strong base (and waterproof if you plan to use the pot 'bare). I also used 4 walls to get a good base around the ridges.
Supports for the centre recess might be a good idea - you don't need support in the radial area, and might want to leave a good Z-gap so the support comes off easily.

Middle Part
Centre the model on top of first part. There is a registration part at Z=0, so once it's centred, the base and middle should be flush.
No base layer.
No top layer.
Wall thickness 1 (or as you chose). Although this part is solid, we print it so only the walls come out.

Top Part
Centre in the same way as the middle part.
This part of the model needs infill.

With the 3 models stacked one on top of the other, Cura (3.0.3 here) will generate a printable model, but i strongly recommend you check the transitions in a gcode viewer (http://gcode.ws) before printing since this is a multi-hour print.

I've included a one-part model too, but this probably won't work in vase mode, and might not give good results if you try printing it 'as is'.

I used PLA, for resiliance and ease of gluing...

description.text: Bandit emblem just for fun, be sure to check out the other emblems I created!

This is officially called a "precast concrete temporary barrier" but is usually called a "jersey barrier" since they are used extensively on highways in New Jersey. This one was designed by a friend of mine who is a civil engineer, John Mastronardi. It is scaled to 1/87 of full size for use with HO scale models. It also can be scaled down 54% for use with N scale models.

John Mastronardi designed this in AutoCad. I printed it on a MakerBot Replicator2 using MakerWare 2.4 with the following settings and no raft: Infill = 10%
Layer Height = 0.200
Shells = 1
Feedrate = 40
Travel Feed = 55
Temperature = 220 It took 17 minutes to print.

  • Mounting plate is now 4.xmm instead of 2.5mm (sensor has same distance to nozzle)
  • The sensor is fixed by two 3mm x 12mm screws

title: Small Vertical Mount Open Tool Box

description.text:
Small 80x35x30mm open box for your small common 3D printer tools such as tweezers, knife, etc. Mounts vertical to the side of your printer or wall. Can be mounted via commercially available disc neodymium magnets, a strip of thick double-sided tape, or magnetic tape. If using magnets, DO NOT place by the printer's sensitive components. Comes with an 8mm hex key wrench holder on the side. Two designs--one with thinner walls and bracing and another with a plain smooth surface.

Note that if your printer uses support material, use needle nose pliers to remove the material. Makes it easy to remove.

title: Watering Nozzle | Embout Arrosoir pour Bouteille

description.text:
Watering Nozzle for Bottles - Embout Pour Transformer une Bouteille en Arrosoir

EN
Watering Nozzle for "Hépar" bottles, to transform them into precise plant-watering bottles (for indoor plants by exemple). The bottle input diameter is 28mm : if this size doesn't please you, don't forget to use the "multiply size" of your 3D printing software or to modify the Sketchup file to print it in the right dimensions ;). To stick together the bottle and the nozzle I used hot glue and black scotch for aesthetic and it works well. You can fill in the bottle in a sink even when it is close to parallel to the ground if you close the end of the nozzle with your finger.

FR
C'est un embout pour transformer les bouteilles plastiques (le diamètre de l'embout est de 28mm, c'est à dire une bouteille d' "hépar" mais en fonction de votre logiciel d'impression 3D il est possible de multiplier la taille de l'objet ou même modifier le fichier .skp pour avoir les bonnes dimensions ;) ) en un arrosoir précis et remplissable dans tous les éviers (pour les plantes d’intérieur par exemple). Il y a 2 versions : celle avec le rebord (plus dure à imprimer mais sans aucuns débordements) et celle sans. Pour le fixer j'ai utilisé de la colle chaude (et du scotch pour l’esthétique) et cela ne fuit pas. Vous pouvez Remplir la bouteille dans un petit évier même en mettant la bouteille parallèle au sol si vous bouchez le bout avec votre doigt.

title: Rickenbacker Guitar Rogan Oven Style Knobs
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Rickenbacker guitars back in the 60's had these cool Rogan Oven (or Stove) style knobs, which were made famous by John Lennon. Here's a version that you can print. In fact, I used them on my 3D printed Rickenbacker 325 homage electric guitar:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2581323
You can also download the STL files for the pickguard, guitar body, and neck at the link above, as well as find a link to a YouTube video about the design and construction of that guitar, and see a four song performance featuring it.
Other guitar knobs I've designed:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2595477
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2596494

Printer:

MakerFarm 12" i3v

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm per layer

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed them in black PLA, then switched to gold for the last millimeter, so they are top in a contrasting color, similar to John lennon's.

I capped them with a layer of clear doming epoxy for a nice finished look, but this is optional.
Also, you may have to drill out the center hole if its too tight for your potentiometers.

I recommend using three walls and printing these at 0% infill. They will be very strong and don't need to be heavy, because the magnets ensure they won't fly away.

Magnets

The magnet recess is designed for a 6mm x 3mm disc magnet. I used superglue to attach them, but you could use your adhesive of choice.
Just a remix of a 15mm bed bracket for hypercube evolution

The zip on my jacket broke, but fortunately, I had recently finished building a 3D printer! So, like any good 3D printerer, I took the broken zip parts, measured them up, modelled them in Solidworks and printed a new one! It works great, and prints in less time than it would take me to drive into town, buy a new zip and come back! http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-SNgIFB3kvM (Sorry for the Solidworks model, I'm planning on getting familiar with free 3D CAD packages so that anyone can modify the design.)

There are two files to download: Zipper and Zipper with small slot. I've been using the Zipper.stl file, but as requested, I've uploaded a version with a smaller slot size in order to increase the amount of plastic around the slot for strength. So, if you're having trouble with the slot breaking, please try the Zipper with small slot file.  
You'll probably need to print this with a brim as the half of the slider without the handle has a small surface area and can get knocked off. I've used a 5mm brim myself.  
I've printed and tested this using a 0.2mm layer height and it works great.

description.text:
This is a replacement leg for a toy robot my son was given as a present.

Unfortunately both of the legs were broken in the box when he opened it.

The original legs as I discovered were..... I'll be polite here, were let's just say they were a
little delicate!

There was almost no difference between left and right legs, so print one or two, it fits both sides.
The leg is in two parts to make it easier to print, just superglue them together as in the picture.

I guess there is only a slim chance that anyone in the world will need this.

The casing of the robot can easily be split down the middle, just be careful, the plastic is a little on the brittle side, the 3d printed leg is probably the toughest part.

0.8mm shell
0.1mm layer height
10% infill (it's hollow so probably not needed)

print_settings.Notes:: PLA is a great material for this device.

description.text:
This is a simple to make device that makes calibrating your extruder's E-steps a snap. It can be used on direct drive extruders, extruders with a Bowden tube and even remote direct drive extruders, You just need to have access to the top of the extruder where the filament feeds in. The results are very reproducible. The heart of the tool is an inexpensive digital caliper. I prefer the lightweight plastic/CF calipers. You can get them at Amazon in the US: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01LW1V1B1/ref=dp_sp_detail?psc=1

These calipers measure to the nearest 0.1mm - which is fine for this application. You can use the common steel calipers but they are a little more unwieldy to use.

Print the Caliper Mount.stl and the appropriate FIlament Guide (1-75 or 2-85) for your printer.

I've also included STEP files if anyone wants to modify the tool.

The g-code script for 1.75mm extruders is included in the files. I don't have a 2.85mm printer (surprisingly) so if someone wants to test let me know what happens. The 1.75mm script might extrude too fast for a 2.85mm extruder.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

PLA is a great material for this device.

Assembly

To complete assembly you'll need:

1) two M3 set screws (aka grub screws)
2) one M3 nut
3) an M3x12mm thumb screw or cap screw

One grub screw holds the caliper in the slot at the top of the Caliper Mount. It is best to pre-tap this hole with an M3 tap, but you can simply thread in the set screw if you prefer.

The other grub screw holds the caliper's depth gauge in the Filament Guide. Print the filament guide appropriate for your filament/extruder - either 1.75mm or 2.85mm. The M3 nut is pressed into the hexagonal pocket in the back of the Filament Guide. I used a longer M3 screw to pull it into the pocket. The thumb screw threads into it from the front side.

Clean up the parts after printing and make sure the Filament Guide slides smoothly along the entire length of the Caliper Mount's track. Then attach the caliper to the Caliper Mount with the set screw. The 4mm diameter hole on the left side of the Caliper Mount provides access to tighten the set screw in the Filament Guide.

Once you have the tool assembled, watch my video on how to use it to calibrate your extruder: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0Mnq5SfXVSA

CalibrateExtruder-1-75mm.g

; This is the g-code that extrudes 100mm of filament for a 1.75mm extruder.
;
; Simply run it as a macro in RepRapFirmware or print it like g-code. It will beep and
; then pause for 10 seconds so you can set things up. Then it beeps again and starts
; the calibration.
;
G21 ; millimeters
M83 ; relative extruder moves
T0 ; select the first extruder
M300 S300 P800
G4 S10 ; wait 10 seconds to get set up
M300 S300 P500
G1 E0 ; set extruder 1 to 0
G1 E10 F30 ; extrude 10mm at .5mm/s
G1 E10 F60 ; extrude 10mm at 1mm/s
G1 E10 F120 ; extrude 10mm at 2mm/s
G1 E10 F180 ; extrude 10mm at 3mm/s
G1 E10 F180 ; extrude 10mm at 3mm/s
G1 E10 F180 ; extrude 10mm at 3mm/s
G1 E10 F120 ; extrude 10mm at 3mm/s
G1 E10 F120 ; extrude 10mm at 2mm/s
G1 E10 F60 ; extrude 10mm at 1mm/s
G1 E10 F30 ; extrude 10mm at .5mm/s

circular vase setting in Slic3r

Notes:

Printed in PLA
Printed in two pieces and welded together with a soldering iron

We are always trying to minimize the mass on the printer. That way we can print a little faster or get a better result. We then add a lot of mass to the printhead by attaching a fan to it so we can cool things down. I decided to try and do it a little better and hence what you see in the model and the pictures.

I made a duct out of liquid latex by brushing it on a piece of PVC tube. The duct around the printhead is a single shell circular vase print. I printed it in two parts and welded them together with a soldering iron. It is all printed in PLA. If there is a good amount of interest in this I will put up more information, or drop me a comment.

description.text:
ENGLISH:
This is a design my own to my imagination of "The Emerald Sword". The scriptures are in Phoenician, to somehow imitate the emerald tablet (also known as Smaragdine Table, or Tabula Smaragdina) of Hermes Trismegistus, which has its hermetic connection with the Rhapsody's sagas (Rhapsody or Rhapsody of fire is a symphonic power metal band). I add 3 holes not only for an aesthetic question but also to represent that it takes the 3 keys of wisdom to find the way to obtain this sword.

ESPAÑOL:
Este es un diseño propio a mi imaginación de "The Emerald Sword". Las escrituras que tiene están en Fenicio, para de alguna manera imitar a la tabla de esmeralda de Hermes Trismegisto, la cual tiene su conexión hermética con las sagas de Rhapsody. Le agregue 3 orificios no solo por una cuestión estética, sino también para de representar que se necesitan las 3 llaves de la sabiduría para encontrar el camino para obtener esta espada.

description.text: My faucet Aerator was clogged when i moved in . I just avoided that bathroom. Taking the aerator out would result in my pants getting sprayed. So I designed a 3d printable aerator that fits the faucet and draws air in around the edges to increase spray pressure but reduce water flow. It works great but I had to clean up the part with a 1mm drill bit I got from a specialty store because it's proven tricky to get small features inside to print cleanly. The water jets spray into an internal chamber, where air gets drafted in and both air and water merge together through larger venturii before exiting the faucet head.

title: Tangram, 七巧板, Recreational math, Pedagogy

description.text:
The Tangram, known as “七巧板,” is “a Chinese puzzle made by cutting a square of thin material into five triangles, a square, and a rhomboid which are capable of being recombined in many different figures” (Merriam Webster). Simple as it is, it has been used in recreational and formal mathematics for centuries, affording students of all ages meaningful and surprising mathematical explorations and insights. Today, one can design much more complicated puzzles in a tangram style. However, the original tangram set holds its aesthetic appeal.

The Tangram can be used as an introductory 3D design project with Fusion 360 or any other 3D design software: parameters, sketches, basic constraints, extrusion, and 3D navigation. I added a little variety to the designs using “offsets,” “circles,” and “fillets,” just to make it more personal. It would be great for students to design their own Tangram and then use them to explore its mathematical structures from shapes to proportions.

Here, the big square is 100mm by 100mm, with two choices for thickness, 3mm and 4mm.

References

  1. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/tangram
  2. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangram
  3. Read, R. C. (1965). Trangrams: 330 puzzles. Dover Recreational Math. Dover Publications.
  4. http://www.archimedes-lab.org/tangramagicus/pagetang1.html

title: Tripod mount for Logitech C310 Webcam

description.text:
[update: added one 5mm taller so C310 can be angled down a bit more. Useful for mounting positions above the bed.]

I like the C310 webcam - it's inexpensive and the resolution is pretty good - certainly good enough for monitoring 3D prints. The problem with that is the standard clamp mount it's attached to. Good for hanging off of computer monitors, but not so good for anything else.

The first problem is getting the clamp-mount off the camera. Very easy and quick, once you know how - I've included a small series of photos describing the completely-reversible process.

The simple mount I designed attaches to the camera exactly as the clamp mount did, but with a smaller hinge and an M3 screw for the hinge pin. The first one I made needed an M3x25, of which I had plenty in my bins. I made a second one a bit narrower, using the more common M3x20. Either one needs an M3 nut (Nylock preferred) to hold everything together and allow the camera to be held in position. I've found that there's no need to screw it down it very tightly. With the original white bushing in place, the camera can be held in place and still be adjusted without having to dig out your hex wrench.

I used the NutJob library https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193647 to tap a 1/4 x 20 hole in the bottom to take a standard tripod screw. I also used it to create the included thumbscrews that may come in handy for some situations.

I originally made the mount with a wider base for stability in the project I was using it in. I've also included one with a narrower base..

I should also mention that the C310 has a fixed focus set to capture a talking head from a distance of about 2-3 feet to infinity. This is not really practical for a 3D printer camera. The good news is that it is only fixed because there is no user-access. But if you pop off the faceplate (it has snaps) and remove the three tiny screws holding the cover in place, you can turn the lens ring a little bit counter-clockwise (as you look into the lens) and bring the focus closer. Get it where you like it and button it back up,

title: Hiking Pole Clips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Clips for Hiking Poles with Hinge and Clasp

These clips are designed to securely lock around a pair of hiking poles while in use, so the weight-bearing pole carries the other one. The clips feature a captured hinge mechanism with loose tolerances suitable for printing at lower resolutions. When both poles are being held by the clip, the tension on the mechanism locks the clasp in place.

In the example photos, two clips are used for extra stability, but it is functional with just one.

Why?

Many people with mobility issues use hiking poles (or similar) rather than dedicated medical devices like canes or walkers to help them get around. Those with fatigue issues in particular may only use a single pole to get around most of the day, but may need both poles when walking longer distances. Carrying the second pole under your arm is awkward and can make it hard to carry things with your free hand. These clips allow the second pole of a pair to be carried hands-free.

Acknowledgements

This project would not have been possible without the help of the Maker Hub at the Eugene Public Library; thank you to all of the volunteers! Special thanks to Mariah for field testing and feedback.

This is a project that my son and I did. It was inspired by:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2481483
(the io shield is actually just his brought over ... no need to redesign that part.)

However, we wanted the Pi to control the fans as well as the printer power.
I'd love to say we carefully measured the hole in the case, but reality is that we placed the mounted pi in place, marked one corner (above the USB port) on the inside, cut through, then used that as a reference to cut the 54x20mm hole on the outside. Likewise, once the hole was cut we put epoxy on the mount and placed it where it needed to be (using the pi itself as a reference). We epoxied the buck converter mount to a sidewall out of the way.

Once you have your parts, connect the Buck Converter to a 12v DC powersource and connect the output to a multimeter and adjust the power to be 5.0v DC to power both the Pi and the Relay board.

Then hook the rest up as described in the wiring diagram. Connect the main power line from the CR-10 to relay 1 center post and use 16 guage wire to connect relay 1 to the main power on the motherboard. Then use the smaller wires to connect everything else.

We used the following parts:
Raspberry Pi 3b:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01CD5VC92

4 channel relay:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KTEN3TM

Buck Converter:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008BHAOQO

While we were in there, we swapped out the 40mm case fan and the 50mm cooling fan with quieter ones (specifically these):
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00261ABFK
and
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B071W93333

Between everything that used to be hardwired (the fans, the buck converter, etc) we installed disconnects:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06WGN56V2

to jump from the raspberry pi to the relay we used these:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00M5WLZDW

(those last two can be bought in less bulk but my son is studying electronics so we bought lots)

Motherboard connections are explained in this video:
http://youtu.be/2zfKGbwtR-A

The relay with the pi (and some starter scripts) are explained in this video:
http://youtu.be/OQyntQLazMU

I used #4 machine screws as I could not get 2.5mm screws long enough to go through the spacers.

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20

Get confident with the relay board

Watch the video in the summary. Connect the Pi to a powersource, wire up the relay as shown in the video ... Make sure it all makes sense.

Design the mounting brackets

We measured boltholes in the boards. We made sparse mounting plates to epoxy to the inside of the CR-10. We designed standoffs to raise the realy above the pi. We cut out a section of the relay mounting board to expose the GPIO pins.

Wire everything up

This is the scary part. Be sure to disconnect power. Be sure to reconnect everything carefully when you're done.

Whilst building the PALZero by ajcraig I came across several errors. One being that the button mount is the incorrect model and that the middle button hole is too big to fit the push button listed in the BOM. If you look closely at his build pictures, you can see his prints do not include this bigger button hole.

I have also reorientated all the STLs ready to print.

I have used pretty much all the same materials that ajcraig has used. If you want to have a cooling fan, you will need a small 5v fan and a transistor (I used a S8050 NPN transistor).

I must stress that ajcraigs models and guide are really good and was very well written. There are problems thought and I thought I would help out by sharing what I did to complete the project.

Introduction

I too have built ajcraigs PALZero. Whilst I found his guide really well done, it was quite lacking in certain areas and some of the STL's were wrong. Also there was some changes I made for my own tastes. One of them being I wanted to have the 3rd USB port accessible (I simply cut a spot in the side of the case for it, and just hot glued it in place, wiring it onto the 3rd usb port). I also wired mine differently, which I will explain below.

I have also solved the problem of no information on how to setup the software. By doing this I have cobbled together a PALZero service script that that not only monitors the eject & shutdown button, but also can turn a fan on and off with a transistor. I have included a way to have background music playing whilst selecting games without taking away from the emulators performance.

The way I have it setup, is that the "reset" button shuts down the raspberry pi gracefully, and the eject button will quit any emulator you have running. You can have it so the shutdown button will reset if pressed and shutdown if held down. However I found that in testing it was unnecessary.

Fan

Fan hot glue and shim Fan air shim

I have installed the fan in such a way that it draws in via the fans on the top case. I have used hot glue to hold it in place, I used a small shim of plastic to ensure that it only draws from those vents.

I accidentally broke the fan case a while back, and decided to just cut that side out to try and force the air flow out the side more.

I also added a small shim of plastic between the HDMI adaptor and usb hub input cable to force the airflow through the raspberry pi heatsink. For the shims I used an old ice cream container.

I was planning on modelling a fan holder and some air guides, but I ran out of time as this was a present.

The fan has reduced the temperature by 10ºc on average and the parts I had laying around so it was no added cost for me.

Wiring

General wiring GPIO wiring up close

Wiring with ajcraigs setup was a little overkill. Raspberry Pi's have internal pull up resistors that can be enabled on the GPIO. Unless I have missed something, these should suffice for dealing with simple buttons. I have also powered the LED from the GPIO that is the UART/serial pins.

The two diagrams above should tell you everything you need to know. Obviously the DC motor is actually a fan, do not hook a standard dc motor up to your raspberry pi! Use a 5v brushless fan.

Setup the raspberry pi software!

Step 1

Extract the software.zip file, this includes scripts needed to make the software work!

Step 2

To enable the status LED, edit your /boot/config.txt and add the following to the end

enable_uart=1

this will allow the LED to turn on when the raspberry pi is running, and off when it is off or in standby.

Step 3

Next we are going to install the PALZero service that deals with the buttons and the optional 5v cooling fan.

  1. copy palzero.service to /etc/systemd/system
  2. copy bin/ folder to /home/pi
  3. make sure both scripts in /home/pi/bin/ are executeable (ie: chmod +x ~/pi/bin/*)

Step 4

Optional!

Next we are going to add the ability to have background music that runs whilst outside of an emulator.

  1. Install the required software: sudo apt-get install mpg123
  2. copy the 3 script files included in the scripts/ folder to /opt/retropie/configs/all/

  3. place mp3 files into RetroPie/roms/music and the music will be played at random at startup (requires rebooting to add new songs)

Sources

  • shutdown down button - https://gilyes.com/pi-shutdown-button/
  • button tutorial - http://razzpisampler.oreilly.com/ch07.html (confirmation that pull up resistors are not needed for other pins, and software pull up resistors are fine)
  • transistor FAN tutorial - https://hackernoon.com/how-to-control-a-fan-to-cool-the-cpu-of-your-raspberrypi-3313b6e7f92c
  • LED tutorial - https://howchoo.com/g/ytzjyzy4m2e/build-a-simple-raspberry-pi-led-power-status-indicator
  • Emulation station background music - https://retropie.org.uk/forum/topic/347/background-music-continued-from-help-support/43

title: 18mm model rocket engine storage box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Storage frame for 18mm model rocket engines. It holds up to 5 per stack and has 6 stacks. If you print the one with the sides tilted at the bottom, it is sized to fit in an old red toolbox under the lift out tray.

The stacks have slots on the sides to aid in lifting the engines out when they are down at the bottom, and sloping top sides to make it easier to drop engines in and take them out.

The design is intended to print without supports, as long as you can bridge 2cm. If you can't bridge that far, the slots on the end could be filled in, they were added purely to reduce print volume and time. The side slots are 1cm, if your printer can't bridge those, you could either print with supports and do cleanup, or fill them in.

This is sized to support 18mm engines such as Estes A, B and C sized engines. If anyone is interested in matching 24mm or 13mm I could probably design one... I just don't fly either of those. Next I'll likely do trays for 24mm or 29mm reloads.

Prusa

If your slicer is capable of multiple layer heights, I highly recommend printing the bottom cm or so, and the top cm or so in thin layers to get smoother curves and points, but print the middle section that's just boring straight lines as thick as you can for time.

I wanted a way to level wooden parts on my CNC router an easier way than using shims and trial and error. I found software that would do it for me by using a probe and Mach3. The software is G Code Ripper found here http://www.scorchworks.com/Gcoderipper/gcoderipper.html
To use the software I needed a probe I designed this probe a bit different than most. My idea was to be able to probe with the tool I am going to use when cutting the part, so that the only offset I will need while probing will be an offset for the Z. The Z offset is the length of the probe which is the length of the bolt I used for the probe.
This probe mounts on a Bosch Colt router mount from Inventables https://www.inventables.com/technologies/bosch-colt-spindle-mount
Here is a link to a YouTube Video of the probe in action https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ei4Fv9O2lHs&feature=youtu.be

Other than the printed parts I used .
Wire
Two 1/4 20 x 3 1/2 inch bolts
One 1/4 x 3/4 bolt
One piece of aluminum strap 1 inch wide and about 1 1/2 long
Two #8 flat head screws and nuts
Four springs large enough to slide over the 3 1/2 bolts
Two 1/4 inch washers

There are several YouTube videos with instructions on using G Code Ripper with Mach3
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yq_j3nZeFsM

This is the first try I am sure I will make improvements would like to hear for anyone that uses my idea or improves it. There are two supports that will have to be remover from the part that slides onto the router mount.

PS That is not me in the instructional video the video is to show how G Code Ripper works

title: Battery Holder for 4s 26650 Pack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a battery holder for a 4s pack of 26650 size cells. I made this primarily for powering my Sound Devices MixPre-D, but you could use it for other stuff too. It consists of 3 parts.... a case, an inner support that holds the threaded inserts, and a cap to mount the switch, voltmeter, and power connector.

If you don't want to use the Hirose connector, the hole will fit a coaxial power connector just fine. I've included an STL for the cap that has no cutouts, so you can make your own.

Parts list:
8 6-32 threaded inserts on the part labeled "4s V2 Inner": (McMaster PN 93365A132)
8 Button head socket cap 6-32 x 3/8in screws
1 Mini rocker switch whose part number is "MINI1SW" (hole is 9mm x 14mm)
1 Hirose connector part number: HR10A-7R-4S (hole is 8.5 mm diameter)
1 Mini LED voltmeter (hole is 23mm x 15mm)

title: Anet A8 30A power supply cover with toggle switch and usb charger output
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This remix is for this style power supply, switched plug socket, and usb charger:

http://amzn.to/2CxCMfR (30A DC Universal Regulated Switching Power Supply 360W)
http://amzn.to/2EM13gC (Power Socket with Fuse and Switch)

  • There are two styles of socket, the diamond one that has screws and this one that just clicks in, make sure you are getting the right one or you'll need to drill screw holes or remix

It also uses a separate toggle switch to turn the printer on and off while the USB charging ports are still on so you can charge your USB devices from this power supply without the printer being turned on. This is great because it lets you use this as a high powered charger for your phone or tablet too. These power supplies are awesome because you can adjust the output voltage and the built-in thermostat will turn the fan on when it needs to, otherwise it will be silent

http://amzn.to/2qlRAcy (Heavy-Duty Toggle Switch)
http://amzn.to/2lRi3t9 (12V to 5V 3A dual usb power adapter/charger)

My issue with the original is that it covers up some of the air vents, making the cooling fan less efficient

You'll also need a bracket (one that doesn't put power supply too close to the frame):
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2599420

The screws you'll need:
http://amzn.to/2lP1gal (m3 assortment)
http://amzn.to/2CjVKU8 (m4 countersunk)

Before ordering them, check old computers or other electronics, these screws are pretty common and you probably have a bunch laying around the house and not even realize it

These are the terminals I used:
http://amzn.to/2EPbPCH
http://amzn.to/2lSkE6n
http://amzn.to/2ER1SVA
And a crimper if you don't already have one:
http://amzn.to/2Cluxk1

I made the 2 wires going to printer quick disconnects so I can assemble switches and all the other wires and then connect the printer ones when I'm putting on cover

I combined a 30mm fan duct with a filament cooler duct.
I am taking about one third of the air from the heat sink and diverting it to the filament on the bed. I wanted to minimize the weight on my effector and I wanted to cool the heat sink and the printed material with one fan.
I got tired of this thing breaking when I snap it on and off so I added a rib on the sides for some extra strength.
There is a tiny 5mm brim - trim away post print.
And the screw holes for the fan should be drilled out a little.
No supports
No rafts
No fat chicks
I would print this in ABS due to the temperature it will be exposed to
(hence the 5mm brim)

And I made a stand alone diverter. You can sandwich this thing between a 30mm fan and an E3D V6 heat sink shroud.You will need some long skinny screws though.

A charm or amulet made from 5 irregular but identical pentagons arranged in a circle. The vertices are consecutively numbered and the sums of the numbers at the vertices at each of the 5 pentagrams are the same. They could be used to decorate birthday or anniversary cards and cakes.

Eighteen of the charms are numbered from 1 through 16 and have sums which vary from 34 through 51. However, while remaining consecutive, the numbers at the vertices can be changed to produces sums from 0 to 100. Instructions are given in the openSCAD code.

Ten examples are given here, sums are 0, 34, 37, 41, 43, 44, 48, 50, 51 and 100. Many others can be generated with the openSCAD code.
